p: It is known that the CCR5 protein interferes in the clinical course of WNV infection ( Glass et al., 2005; Diamond, 2009; Michlmayr and Lim, 2014), but the effects of CCR5Δ32 on the susceptibility to this infection and disease progression are different. According to Lim et al. (2010) and Danial-Farran et al. (2015), CCR5Δ32 has no important effect on susceptibility to WNV infection. In accordance, Loeb et al. (2011) found no association between CCR5Δ32 and WNV infection. Conversely, there is robust population-based data showing a strong association between the CCR5Δ32 homozygous genotype and increased risk of developing symptomatic WNV infection ( Glass et al., 2006; Lim et al., 2008, 2010). Also, Bigham et al. (2011) showed that the CCR5Δ32 variant was associated with symptomatic WNV infection when the dominant model of inheritance was considered in the analysis. A recent meta-analysis confirmed the role of the CCR5 gene in WNV infection, specifically the association between the CCR5Δ32 with severe disease ( Cahill et al., 2018). Table 1 summarizes the results of the studies that evaluated the CCR5Δ32 genetic variant in the context of human WNV infection.
